update.description:
This adds visualization markers to gazebo. The interface to markers is through ignition transport. Included in this pull request is a new example stand-alone executable, and `gz marker` command line tool.

The [ignition::msgs::Marker](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/07607e5f1e77eceec0273f6c73cee5aaa5768fe4/ignition/msgs/marker.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) message type is used to create, modify, and destroy markers.

For command line usage help: `gz marker -h`
update.title: Markers

content.raw: How about using a [Service without input parameter](http://ignition-transport.readthedocs.io/en/ign-transport2/services/services.html#service-without-input-parameter) for `OnList`?
content.html: How about using a Service without input parameter for OnList?

content.raw:
I tried `gz marker -a -t sphere -i 88`. I don't see anything in the scene, I'd expect a unit sphere to show at the world origin...

I put some print statements in the code and I noticed that a marker is indeed being created, and it can be deleted with `gz marker -x`.
content.html:
I tried gz marker -a -t sphere -i 88. I don't see anything in the scene, I'd expect a unit sphere to show at the world origin...

I put some print statements in the code and I noticed that a marker is indeed being created, and it can be deleted with gz marker -x.

content.raw: Maybe mention cube/box? The detailed help only mentions box, while the options only mention cube. It's probably nice to be consistent
content.html: Maybe mention cube/box? The detailed help only mentions box, while the options only mention cube. It's probably nice to be consistent

content.raw: The API for publishing messages using `ignition-transport3` has changed and Gazebo is still not ready to use it. I think the bump to use Ignition-transport3 should include the appropriate changes to use the new API (probably accompanied by a 3.0.0 release to make Jenkins happy).
content.html: The API for publishing messages using ignition-transport3 has changed and Gazebo is still not ready to use it. I think the bump to use Ignition-transport3 should include the appropriate changes to use the new API (probably accompanied by a 3.0.0 release to make Jenkins happy).

content.raw:
Nevermind, I just noticed there are two `ProcessMaterialMsg` functions.

It might be interesting to start writing conversion functions between `ignition::msgs` and `gazebo::msgs` to avoid this kind of duplication.
content.html:
Nevermind, I just noticed there are two ProcessMaterialMsg functions.

It might be interesting to start writing conversion functions between ignition::msgs and gazebo::msgs to avoid this kind of duplication.

content.raw: What do you think of printing an error and returning false in case the marker is not found? It could indicate to the user that their request was malformed. On the other hand, this could become spammy if the user calls it multiple times to delete the same marker...

content.raw:
This file gets installed, and is used by others to compile code against gazebo. `SearchForStuff` is used internally by gazebo for compilation. Try commenting out lines 192-194 and then compile a program that uses gazebo and ignition-transport, such as the example included in this pull request.

I changed this pull request to require ign-transport2 or ign-transport3.
content.html:
This file gets installed, and is used by others to compile code against gazebo. SearchForStuff is used internally by gazebo for compilation. Try commenting out lines 192-194 and then compile a program that uses gazebo and ignition-transport, such as the example included in this pull request.

I changed this pull request to require ign-transport2 or ign-transport3.

update.title: Markers

content.raw:
I'm not sure what's the difference between searching for things in this file or in `SearchForStuff`, pull request #2420 is adding a [check](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2420/get-plugin-info-with-ignition-transport/diff#Lcmake/SearchForStuff.cmakeF703T705) to `SearchForStuff` for ign-transport and that seemed to be enough. It also adds "found" messages so it's easy to find out which version was picked up.

In any case, if I only have ign-transport1, I get compile errors like these:

~~~
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc: In member function ‘bool gazebo::rendering::MarkerManager::Init(gazebo::rendering::Scene*)’:
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc:117:64: error: no matching function for call to ‘ignition::transport::Node::Advertise(const char [8], void (gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate::*)(const ignition::msgs::Marker&), std::unique_ptr<gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate>::pointer)’
         &MarkerManagerPrivate::OnMarkerMsg, this->dataPtr.get()))
~~~
content.html:
I'm not sure what's the difference between searching for things in this file or in SearchForStuff, pull request #2420 is adding a check to SearchForStuff for ign-transport and that seemed to be enough. It also adds "found" messages so it's easy to find out which version was picked up.

In any case, if I only have ign-transport1, I get compile errors like these:

/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc: In member function ‘bool gazebo::rendering::MarkerManager::Init(gazebo::rendering::Scene*)’:
/home/louisep/code/gazeboA/gazebo/rendering/MarkerManager.cc:117:64: error: no matching function for call to ‘ignition::transport::Node::Advertise(const char [8], void (gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate::*)(const ignition::msgs::Marker&), std::unique_ptr<gazebo::rendering::MarkerManagerPrivate>::pointer)’
         &MarkerManagerPrivate::OnMarkerMsg, this->dataPtr.get()))

content.raw: Made the service a "one-way" request. No response is returned.
content.html: Made the service a "one-way" request. No response is returned.
